titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lady Mary Hamilton Papers
titlestmt.author: by Diane J. Ducharme

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:55

did.unittitle: Lady Mary Hamilton papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Series I, Letterbook of Lady Mary Hamilton, contains correspondence by and to the author Lady Mary Hamilton, principally with her daughter Betsey Walker Thiébault and her son-in-law Paul Thiébault; her siblings, including Anne Leslie Carnegie, Countess of Northesk, and Alexander Leslie; and with George Robinson Hamilton and Sir Herbert Croft. Series II, Family Papers, contains a detailed biographical memoir of Lady Mary by her grandson, Baron Adolphe Thiébault.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased on the James Marshall Osborn Fund, 2001.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Lady Mary Hamilton Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lady Mary Hamilton Papers. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: The collection is also available on microfilm.

bioghist.head: LADY MARY HAMILTON, 1739-1816
bioghist.p: Lady Mary Hamilton was born Lady Mary Leslie, youngest daughter of Alexander Leslie, 5th Earl of Leven and Melville, and Lady Elizabeth Monypenny Leslie. She married Dr. James Walker of Innerdovat, physician to the prison hospital in Edinburgh, on January 5, 1762. It was said to have been a "romantic" match, but she and Walker came to lead very separate lives.

According to her grandson, Lady Mary bore ten children, several of whom died in infancy. In 1782 she met and became involved with George Robinson Hamilton, a cousin of the Duke of Hamilton, and removed to France with him and two of her daughters, Betsey and Isabella. After the French Revolution, Betsey married Paul Thiébault, who became General Thiébault, while Isabella married Etienne de Jouy.

Lady Mary Hamilton, as she styled herself, was best known for her novel Munster Village (1778), a utopian work depicting a community of women pursuing higher education, but she also published Letters from the Duchess de Crony (1777); The Life of Mrs. Justman (1782); and The Duc de Popoli (1810).

George Robinson Hamilton died in October, 1797. Some time after his death Lady Mary moved to Amiens, where Sir Herbert Croft became a member of her household. She died there early in 1816, shortly before Croft himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lady Mary Hamilton Papers consist of letters and family papers documenting aspects of the life of Lady Mary Hamilton. The papers span the dates 1758-1863, with the bulk of the material dating from the 1790s, and are organized into two series: I. Letterbook of Lady Mary Hamilton ; and II. Family Papers .

Series I, Letterbook of Lady Mary Hamilton
, is housed in Box 1, folders 1-128 and consists of letters and a few other papers which were gathered and bound by her grandson, Baron Adolphe Thiébault. The letters have been disbound but have been kept in the order in which Thiébault arranged them, which is roughly chronological.

The first 44 folders in the series contain letters from Hamilton's relatives and social acquaintances in Scotland and England. Correspondents include her siblings, Alexander Leslie and Anne Leslie Carnegie, Countess of Northesk; Sir Henry Erskine; Henry Dundas; and Lord Balgonie. Topics include Lady Mary's financial needs; plans for the education and careers of her various children, particularly her sons; advice on settling "quietly in the country;" and social news. Folder 9 contains a letter from the Countess of Northesk describing the secret marriage and subsequent disinheritance of her eldest son Lord Rosehill; folder 34 a letter from Henry Dundas declining to assist her in her "case" beyond "barely a mention" of it to Lord North; and folder 37 contains a copy of a poem by Sir Henry Erskine.

There are over forty letters in the collection from Lady Mary to her daughter Betsey Walker Thiébault, addressed to "my dear daughter" or to "Kanker" (a nickname derived from her astrological sign). The letters discuss Lady Mary's and George Hamilton's opposition to, and eventual approval of, Betsey's impending marriage to Thiébault, then a soldier in the Revolutionary Army, as well as her continuing difficulties with her in-laws over dowry and settlement agreements. They also contain news of her siblings and her extended family in Scotland; refer obliquely to political events and developments, particularly Lady Mary's fears of persecution as a foreign national during the Revolutionary period; and reveal Lady Mary's own complex financial problems, which increased after the death of Hamilton in October, 1797.

Other letters include several by Sir Herbert Croft; notes concerning the confiscation of "cheveaux de luxe" by the local Revolutionary committees; six letters from George Robinson Hamilton to various recipients; and notes from Lady Mary to her grandchildren. Folder 95 contains a passport issued to Hamilton by Napoleon's police.

Series II, Family Papers
, is housed in Box 2, folders 129-132 and contains extensive genealogical notes and biographical information compiled by Lady Mary Hamilton's grandson, Baron Adolphe Thiébault. The "histoire de ma famille maternelle" includes Thiébault's impressions of his grandmother and commentary on topics as diverse as the probable paternity of several of her children during her marriage to Walker; analysis of her "romantique" temperment and love of her children; and his view of the character of Sir Herbert Croft.
